ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation in 5-year-old male with proximal muscle weakness, calf pseudohypertrophy, Gowers sign, highly elevated CK, motor delay, and respiratory insufficiency. Age and gender strongly support DMD over Becker MD.
Similar dystrophinopathy presentation but typically milder and later onset than observed. The early age (5 years) with significant weakness and respiratory involvement suggests DMD over BMD.

Reference cases show very similar phenotype including all major features. However, LGMD29 typically includes additional features like developmental cataract and microcephaly not present in this patient.
Gamma-sarcoglycanopathy can present similarly with early onset, high CK, calf hypertrophy, and respiratory involvement, but typically has more prominent distal weakness.
Alpha-sarcoglycanopathy presents with similar features but usually has more severe progression and earlier loss of ambulation than currently observed.
Beta-sarcoglycanopathy can present similarly but typically has more cardiac involvement at this age, which is not reported in this patient.
Dysferlinopathy typically presents later in adolescence or adulthood, making it less likely given the early childhood onset in this 5-year-old patient.
